chapter.title: Hosting Docker Images On-premise
chapter.para: What can be done with the custom Docker images I created? How can they be shared within my organization? The easiest solution would be to push these images to the Docker Hub. By default all images pushed to the Docker Hub are public. This is probably fine as long as this does not violate your companies policy and your images do not contain sensitive data or proprietary software.
If you need to restrict access to your Docker images, there are two possibilities:

listitem.para: Get a subscription on Docker Hub that unlock private repositories.
Run an on-site Docker registry where to store all the Docker images used by your organization or company and combine them with Portus to secure the registry.

chapter.para: This chapter describes how to set up an on-site Docker registry and how to combine it with Portus.

sect1.title: What is a Docker Registry?
sect1.para: The Docker registry is an open source project created by Docker Inc. It allows the storage and retrieval of Docker images. By running a local instance of the Docker registry it is possible to completely avoid usage of the Docker Hub.
The Docker registry is also used by the Docker Hub. However, the Docker Hub, as seen from the user perspective, is made of the following parts at least:

listitem.para: The user interface (UI): The part that is accessed by users with their browser. The UI provides a nice and intuitive way to browse the contents of the Docker Hub either manually or by using a search feature. It also allows to create organizations made by different users.
The authentication component: This is used to protect the images stored inside of the Docker Hub. It validates all push, pull and search requests.
The storage back-end: This is where the Docker images are sent and downloaded from. It is provided by the Docker registry.

note.title: Incompatible Versions of Docker and Docker Registry
note.para: Docker registry version 2.3 is not compatible with Docker versions older than 1.10, because v2 manifests were only introduced with Docker 1.10. As Docker and Docker registry can be installed on different boxes, the versions might be incompatible. If you experience communication errors between Docker and Docker registry, update both to the latest versions.

sect1.title: Limitations
sect1.para: The Docker registry has two major limitations:

listitem.para: It lacks any form of authentication. That means everybody with access to the Docker registry can push and pull images to it. That also includes the possibility to overwrite already existing images.

There is no way to see which images have been pushed to the Docker registry. You can taroth 2015-07-09: maybe replace "can" with "need to"? manually take notes of what is being stored inside of it. There is also no search functionality, which makes collaboration harder.

sect1.para: The next section is going to introduce Portus, the solution to all of the problems above.

sect1.title: Portus
sect1.para: Portus is an authentication service and user interface for the Docker registry. It is an open source project created by &suse; to address all the limitations faced by the local instances of Docker registry.
By combining Portus and Docker registry, it is possible to have a secure and enterprise ready on-premise version of the Docker Hub.
